net.sf.jga.parser
Interface FunctorRef<T>

All Known Implementing Classes:
BinaryFunctorRef, GeneratorRef, UnaryFunctorRef
public interface FunctorRef<T>

Contains and describes a functor being built by the functor parser. Many of the parsing methods return and/or accept instances of this interface that describe a functor, describe its broad type, the number, names, and types of its arguments, and the type returned.

Copyright © 2004-2005 David A. Hall

Author:
David A. Hall

Field Detail

CONSTANT

static final int CONSTANT
value returned by getReferenceType() for constants. A constant is by definition a Generator, and many constant expressions can be evaluated at parse time.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

IDENTITY

static final int IDENTITY
value returned by getReferenceType() when it refers to an Identity. An Identity is by definition a UnaryFunctor, and in many cases, binding an Identity is unnecessary. Singling out this special case reduces the complexity of many functors that are produced.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

GENERATOR

static final int GENERATOR
value returned by getReferenceType() when it refers to a generator.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

UNARY_FN

static final int UNARY_FN
value returned by getReferenceType() when it refers to a unary functor.

See Also:
Constant Field Values

BINARY_FN

static final int BINARY_FN
value returned by getReferenceType() when it refers to a binary functor.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Method Detail

getFunctor

T getFunctor()
Returns the functor to which this refers.

getReturnType

java.lang.Class getReturnType()
returns the type of objects that the current functor returns.

getNumberArgs

int getNumberArgs()
returns the number of arguments that the current functor requires. Currently, the implementations tend to be hard coded.

getArgType

java.lang.Class getArgType(int i)
returns the type of the i'th argument to the current functor.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the current functor takes fewer than i arguments (or if i is < 0)

getArgName

java.lang.String getArgName(int i)
returns the name of the i'th argument to the current functor, as described in the expression being parsed.

Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the current functor takes fewer than i arguments (or if i is < 0)

getReferenceType

int getReferenceType()
returns a value that classifies the functor by the number of arguments that it requires.
